head.p: This catalogue contains transliterations of Sanskrit fragments in the Stein Collection at the British Library.

msItem.title: [Ratnaketuparivarta]
msItem.note: The script represents a transition from the early southern Turkestan Brāhmī to the southern Turkestan Brāhmī (main type). The text corresponds to RKP 124.6-125.7. Cf. AKh, p. 294: “D. III.3. MS. on paper; Brāhmī; No. 2. Two small fragments; from left and right sides of leaf, the former numbered 96. See Note ii.” AKh, p. 295: “Note ii. [by Dr. Hoernle:] No. 2, also one piece of No. 3, make up one almost complete leaf, numbered 96. Size: about 12" 3". Language: Sanskrit. Characters: upright Gupta, of seventh or eighth century. Contents: apparently a Buddhist canonical work.”

msItem.title: [Samādhirājasūtra]
msItem.note: Written in the southern Turkestan Brāhmī (main type). Three times the Central Asian vowel -e is written with a long stroke and a flag-shaped hook to the right, but only once apparently because the Indian -e otherwise would have touched the preceding anusvāra. Five times the looped diacritic sign for -i is written. Cf. the description in AKh I, p. 297: “D. VI.1. MS. on paper; Brāhmī; No. 28. Note xv. Lefthand fragment, 4 1/2" 3", with string-hole, of a leaf numbered 70. Full size, probably 18" 3". Language: Sanskrit. Characters: upright Gupta of seventh or eighth century. Contents: apparently some Buddhist canonical work; on obverse, end of section 43, the beginning of the 44th section being Smarāmy-ahaṃ kalpāṅs-atīta ..., on reverse, end of section 51. [Dr. Hoernle.].” To the same folio belongs Hoernle Or.6403B2(2) [M 3] which contains two fragments which are fitted in a sheet of paper on which a first transliteration (by A.F. Rudolf Hoernle) is written. The right fragment is given here in bold, the left fragment in italics. The text differs considerably from the Sanskrit text known so far [cf. SRS(D) II, pp. 256-259: chapter 17, verses 142c-157c] and also from the Tibetan translation. For the Chinese translation cf. T 639, 15.572a28-b29.

msItem.title: [Saddharmapuṇḍarīkasūtra]
msItem.note: Written in the southern Turkestan Brāhmī (main type). Six times the Central Asian vowel -e is written, but only once apparently because the Indian -e otherwise would have touched the preceding superscribed vowel. There are two separated fragments of Kha. i.60. Fragment Or.8212/25(3) is given here in italics and Kha. i.209 in bold. BB 33, pp. 129f., No. 46]; KN 87.8(?)- 90.2; Wa 38.6(ḥ)-39.33, 214.25(?)-216.20.

msItem.title: [Śūraṃgamasamādhisūtra]
msItem.note: Written in the early southern Turkestan Brāhmī. Cf. Ser III 1435: “Kha. i.96. [...] One small fr., 2 1/2" 2 1/2", remains of 6 ll., from the Śūraṅgamasamādhi-sūtra, giving the name of Dṛḍhamati Bodhisattva.” In the Tibetan translation the text of the fragment corresponds to Peking Kanjur, section Mdo, vol. thu (70), fol. 314a5-b6 = TT 800, vol. 32, p. 86.2.5-3.6; Derge[Taipei] Kanjur, section Mdo sde, vol. da (11), foll. 288a5-b5 = No. 132, vol. 11, p. 534.575.5-576.5. In the Chinese translation of Kumārajīva the corresponding passage is found in T 642, 15.638b-c (translation Śgs §§ 95-98). The fragments Crosby 262/263, Stein Kha. i.303 and Stein unnumbered (SS 41) + Hoernle 151/2 (Or.15001/1) contain the same passage.

msItem.note: Written in the early southern Turkestan Brāhmī. Cf. Ser III, p. 1436: “Kha. i.152. Text metrical, and belongs to a Buddha-stotra, probably of Mātṛceṭa; but it is too scrappy to read with confidence.” One of the fragments contains on side A remains of verses from the Rāhulastava (cf. msItem.title: [Śūraṃgamasamādhisūtra]
msItem.note: There are three fragments, the script is the early southern Turkestan Brāhmī. Cf. Ser III 1437: “Kha. i.189. [...] (1) three frs. of ś ūraṅgamasamādhi (Dṛḍhamati).” 170.1 In the Tibetan translation the text of the fragment corresponds to Peking Kanjur, section Mdo, vol. thu (70), fol. 286a1-b6 = TT 800, vol. 32, p. 75.1.1-2.6; Derge[Taipei] Kanjur, section Mdo sde, vol. da (11), foll. 263a2-b5 = No. 132, vol. 11, p. 526.523.2-524.5. In the Chinese translation of Kumārajīva the corresponding passage is found in T 642, 15.631c (translation Śgs § 21, Nos. 83-100). In verso 5f. the remains of some ślokas are preserved. Cf. Śgs, p. 119, note 43: “In the Tibetan translation, § 21 is followed by a partly versified passage going from folios 286b5-289a3. These stanzas probably did not appear in the original Sanskrit used by Kumārajīva as he certainly would not have omitted to translate them.”

msItem.title: [Udānavarga]
msItem.note: Written in the early southern Turkestan Brāhmī. The text corresponds to the Peyālavarga (Uv 24) and Mitravarga (Uv 25), the double circle covering the first three lines of recto clearly marks the transition of two vargas. The fragment is the first evidence of a Udānavarga manuscript from Khotan, a text which next to the Prātimokṣasūtra is most frequently attested on the northern Silk Road.
